In one important respect the position is less satisfactory than at the end of last month, in that there has been an increase of 28,645 in the number of those who are wholly unemployed.(C.) The further reduction in unemployment during last month cannot, unfor-unfortunately, be taken as indicative of any general improvement in industry. Apart from the normal increased employment in the harvest period, it is largely accounted for by a somewhat artificial stimulus in a few industrial centres. Thus, in the Cotton, and to a lesser extent in the Woollen and Worsted Industries,, the reduction in unemployment is due to a temporary resumption of full-time working after extended holiday stoppages. This also applies to the position in the Jute Industry, where, however, the improvement seems to be of an even more temporary nature. An increase in the available supplies of coal and a further adaptation of plant to the use of oil fuel have contributed to reduce the unemployment in certain other industries, such as the Pottery Trade. Largely owing to the increased imports during the month, employment at the docks has been somewhat more steady.There is, on the other hand, increasing evidence of the disastrous effects of the continuance of the Coal-mining dispute. Shipbuilding and Engineering have suffered a further relapse. In the Iron and Steel Trades, except in a few areas where foreign coal was available, events have also taken a turn for the worse. It appears, moreover, that the paralysis is gradually extending to the Distributive Trades, while the normal slackness in the Motor Industry and in the Tailoring-Trades has doubtless been accentuated this year by the same cause.(D.) Latest Figures.The latest figures of unemployment published are those for the 13th September, giving the total number on the registers as 1,551,924. This is an increase over the position on the 30th August amounting to 2,165, and an increase over a year ago of 160,392. The preliminary figure for the 20th September is 1,532,400, showing a decrease in one week of 19,524.ARTHUR STEEL-MAITLAND.Ministry of Labour,September 28, 1926.
